--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> The key point that is perhaps not clear is that the
> lines
> in the middle are *not* graphs of average
> complexity, but 
> rather of *dominant's complexity*.  

Yes, I understand that.

That was essentially my criticism.  You're comparing:

--The complexity of generational champions (averaged
from 13 separate runs)
--The max and min complexity each generation (averaged
from 5 random runs)

Why not compare:

--The complexity of generational champions in
fitness-based runs
--The average complexity of the entire population in
random-fitness runs

The question you pose in section 6.1 is: "[D]oes the
complexity always increase whether it helps in finding
good solutions or not?"

Wouldn't the latter comparison provide better insight
into answering this question?

You're asking if the complexity always increases.  But
you don't say which complexity you're referring to. 
If you're referring to the overall complexity of the
evolving population, it seems very clear that yes, the
complexity of the population always increases, whether
or not a fitness evaluation is used.

> You see the key underlying issue is that IF
> complexity did
> NOT correlate to superiority in the robot duel, then
> it is
> *possible* in NEAT for the complexity of the highest
> dominant
> solutions NOT to go up.  And the reason it is
> possible is
> because, as the random run lines show, NEAT keeps
> simple 
> solutions around as long as they are competitive.  

You said something similar in an earlier thread.  I
still don't see how the concept of "competitive"
applies to a population with no selection pressure due
to fitness being applied to it.

It seems to me that simple topologies probably persist
in a random-fitness run of NEAT due to the effects of
speciation.

> I think maybe there is some confusion about what is
> being 
> claimed; the claim is not that average complexity in
> NEAT
> runs does not go up.  

Okay...I guess that's the meaning I took away from
your question in 6.1 (Is complexity inevitable?).

> Rather, the claim is that
> increasing
> sophistication is a result of increasing complexity,
> and
> further that the reason increasing complexity pairs
> with
> increasing sophistication is NOT because of some
> nuance of
> NEAT; it is because it is fundamentally advantageous
> to have 
> more structure in this domain.

But in section 6.3 you go on to demonstrate that both
fixed-topology runs and simplification runs show an
increase in fitness.

What that demonstrates to me is that complexification
is not *necessary* to increase performance in this
domain, but that it is a more effective way of
increasing performance in this domain.  Right?

> But
> what about when you are NOT stagnating- that's
> what's 
> interesting- in that case, adding structure opens
> the door
> to more and more sophisticated behavior.
> 
> I don't think anyone who uses NEAT really finds that
> controversial; after all, that's the whole reason we
> are using NEAT isn't it?  ...because we want to be
> able
> to find more and more complex solutions, because we 
> believe that will lead to more and more interesting 
> behavior.  

I certainly believe that NEAT's approach of starting
minimally and complexifying is a very clever and
effective way of searching the solution space of a
given domain.

But I'd probably qualify this last sentence of yours. 
I don't necessarily want to find more complex
solutions...I want to find the best solutions.  That
includes efficiency.  

If I start out with a minimal topology in Tic-Tac-Toe
(99 genes--9 input, 9 output, 81 connections), and
that topology is sufficient to produce a perfect
player, I don't want to evolve something with twice as
many genes.

I think this may be a intellectual trap of sorts. 
We're evolving neural networks, which control the
behavior of a system.  I think it may be misleading to
assume that an increase in the complexity of behavior
of an individual necessarily leads to an increase in
fitness.

Case from biology: Just last night I was watching
"Animal Countdown" (I think that's the name) on Animal
Planet, and they were counting down the "10 Laziest
Animals".  Kind of a subjective estimation, but #6 was
a porcupine.

So this weasel-like animal spotted the porcupine and
decided it wanted to eat it for lunch.  The only way
it was going to do so was going to be if it could flip
the porcupine and attack its soft underbelly.  The
weasel circled the porcupine, looking for an opening. 
The weasel was using fairly sophisticated behavior to
try to deal with its prey.

But what was the porcupine's response?  Do nothing. 
It didn't move an inch.  Why?  Because its morphology
(spines) contributed to its high fitness...its
inability to be attacked).  It didn't need a
sophisticated behavioral innovation to deal with this
predator.  A rabbit, for example, may have very
sophisticated heuristics for evading prey.  But the
porcupine's behavior was extremely simple.  And that
corresponding simplicity of behavior made the
porcupine more fit. 

So complex behavior doesn't necessarily lead to an
increase in fitness...wouldn't you agree?

The same can be said for morphological traits. 
Parasite morphologies often simplify because the body
of a host can often provide the necessary functions of
particular organs, such that parasites with simpler
body designs persist.

Flightless birds are another example.  So are
cave-dwelling lizards who evolve away pigmentation or
eyes.  These simpler morphologies require less energy
and upkeep, and produce fitter organisms for that
particular environment.

Derek
